title: 113_s2764
content: The Act titled "American Livestock Protection and Ranching Opportunity Act of 2014" emphasizes the importance of country-of-origin labeling for meat products to meet consumer demand and ensure food safety. Additionally, it prohibits the importation of fresh meat and meat products from countries with foot-and-mouth disease. Section 10404 of the Animal Health Protection Act prohibits the importation of fresh meat and meat products from countries with foot-and-mouth disease until certified disease-free. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for brucellosis research and compensation in livestock. The Livestock Disease Initiative is outlined in Section 401, focusing on measures to prevent the spread of diseases like foot-and-mouth and brucellosis in imported meat products. The Livestock Disease Initiative in Section 401 establishes a grant program for research on livestock diseases like bovine brucellosis and tuberculosis. Eligible entities include Federal agencies, National Laboratories, universities, research institutions, and State agricultural experiment stations. Priority is given to research on high-priority zoonotic diseases in livestock. The Livestock Disease Initiative in Section 401 establishes a grant program for research on diseases in domestic livestock that may affect public health. Recipients of grants must conduct research on surveillance methods, vaccines, vaccination delivery systems, or diagnostic tests for these diseases. The Secretary may prioritize proposals from entities that provide matching funds for the grants, but it is not a requirement for receiving a grant. Section 1492 of the National Agricultural Research, Extension, and Teaching Policy Act of 1977 does not apply to grants awarded under this section. Authorization of $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2015 to 2018 is provided. Additionally, Section 1501(c) of the Agricultural Act of 2014 is amended to include assistance for losses due to brucellosis. The text chunk discusses assistance for livestock producers affected by brucellosis infection in the Greater Yellowstone Designated Surveillance Area. Eligible producers can receive assistance equal to 60 percent of the monthly feed cost. The text chunk mentions assistance for eligible livestock producers affected by brucellosis in the Greater Yellowstone Designated Surveillance Area, providing 60 percent of the monthly feed cost. SEC. 5 amends the Agricultural Act of 2014 to change livestock indemnity payment rates to 75 percent of the higher of market value or nationwide price. SEC. 6 establishes the Livestock Forage Disaster Program. SEC. 6 amends the Agricultural Act of 2014 to establish the Livestock Forage Disaster Program, allowing for a price adjustment for high-value forage as determined by the Secretary.
